reviewText:
Call of Cthulhu was an experience I will never forget. It was difficult, unforgiving, and unfair for the entire game. It was very glitchy, had a crash or two, and was full of aimless wandering. But it was all worth it in the end. As with most psychological thrillers, the game liked to toy with you in every way, by forcing you to endure absolute horror, figure out impossible puzzles, and continue living knowing that everything around is both a lie and is out to get you. CoC DCotE was grandly successful in using Lovecraft's style of horror, by making you wonder whether or not what you are seeing is real. Did a Deep One just kill that guy? Or did the protaginist kill that guy and only imagined the Deep One? With how often you are alone and surrounded by myths and crazy people, how can you be sure that what you're seeing is really what is happening? You face Fishmen, Deep Ones, a Shoggoth, Flying Polyps, Dagon, Hydra, Servants of Cthulhu, and other such creatures found in Lovecraft's tales as you play through a fantastic reimagining of Shadow Over Innsmouth.

Because of how this game tortured me with constant insanity, endless questions, aimless wandering, failure, difficulty, bugs, and doubt, I probably won't play through this again for a long time. It was a terrifying journey but it was worth it just to finish the game and experience the atmosphere that is Call of Cthulhu.

I go now, for the images that haunt my dreams are too much torture to handle. Everything this game had forced me through was too much. The questions, the wonders, the idea that there may in the future be a sequel, I just cannot handle the stress. So after I have cataloged my experience, I will throw myself to the streets below this home, before the creatures can find me and pressure me into attempting to aquire an A rank through the game. I hear them now. Buy this game, see what I have seen, and you will finally understand. They're at the door now! Scratching! Pounding! I just want it to end! The window! The window!

reviewText:
For the obvious, Call of Cthulhu is a game inspired by Lovecraft. It's called Call of Cthulhu, but that's more of a marketing thing, as Cthulhu actually plays a very little role in the title. The game is more about a few of Lovecraft's other novels, the most notable one being Shadow Over Innsmouth. However, if you don't know the difference between a Cthulhu and a Dagan or a Xa'ligha, that's okay as the game doesn't expect you to know these things, as you play as a character who knows nothing about these things either.

Call of Cthulhu: Dark Corners of the Earth is a first-person horror-adventure game. It has elements of a first-person shooter, an adventure game, and a survival-horror game. It's also a really tough cookie, it's not an easy game, and there is a legitimate survival element, as well as a few tough puzzles, and some pretty fantastic atmosphere and scares.

You play as a man named Jack Walters, who's a detective. The game starts with a prologue section when Jack helps a local police force he's acquainted with break into a house run by a group of cultists. They're shooting-up the police... However, when Jack infiltrates, the cultists don't seem to be hostile towards him, but rather actually welcome him with open arms, as they commit a mass-suicide ritual. And when he enters the basement, he witnesses something strange, and everything becomes a blur. He becomes conscious six years later, when he finds out he spent the last six years in a mental asylum. He has no memory of this time, and to him he was just at the cultists house. He of course is really curious about this time, but tries to resume his detective agency. He receives a letter and takes on the requested case to investigate a missing persons report of a Brian Burnham, a man who tried to start a grocery store chain in a nearby coastal town of Innsmouth. He goes to investigate.

Gameplay has a lot of variety, and fantastic pacing for the most part if you can accept it moves at a bit of a slower pace, a more slow-burn type of game (which benefits it rather than hurts it, I feel). The game has sections of exploration and interaction with townspeople. You actually have a big portion of the game at the beginning when you're defenseless, and have to master skills of stealth, evasion, and survival with taking advantage of the environment and lowly tools you have that are hardly murder weapons. There's puzzles, both in the on-the-fly gameplay sort and the 'need to solve this puzzle to continue' variety. And the game isn't full of scripted scenarios either (though a few do exist), so a lot of the survival has to be taken from your own wits and cleverness.

Survival is important. Gun bullets don't graze you, they can seriously damage you. The game has a mechanic where you bleed when shot, as well as where you are shot effects your damage reaction to being shot. You heal it with limited healing items you get, some to stop bleeding or mend wounded appendages, others to recover blood and health. You also need to be careful as some weapons can inflict poisoning on you to recover from. Eventually you do get a gun though, but the game hardly becomes a run-and-gun, you have to be really strategic and know when to let-go of being undetected to fire, and which enemies are really worth taking out. You have limited ammo, and the enemies can seriously kick your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• if you're not careful.

But the game isn't all about combat and stealth. There also are areas and levels with almost no enemies at all, and some fantastic horror scenes, strange sanity moments, and just some atmosphere and sequences that go in very different directions. The character also has a sanity feature, which makes it so the more he's around unpleasent things, the more weird things may become for him. Certain areas, imagery, and the like help his sanity, while others break it.

The game also has some memorizing music, graphics are obviously a bit outdated but do the job, and as the game continues, situations open up a lot more to how you can approach them. And the game continues adding new elements, additions, and set-piece like moments all the way through to the end to prevent it from becoming too much of the same, and leaving you to continually wonder what might be coming next. It's pacing can be argued is slow, but I think works very well for the title and what its trying to achieve.

I also can mention that this game I would label as a scary game, it is absolutely tense a lot of the time, and some segments legitimately scared the crap out of me. But part of the way it pulls this off is that they're not over-abundant or consistent, and don't rely on the same few tricks or overly on cheap scares.

There is some jank here though, with some bugs, sometimes you may be detected by enemies when they really shouldn't of detected you, and there's a few frustrating parts of the game that are kind of trial-and-error, where basically you need to do what the game wants you to do or you'll die. There are some fan patches to address some of these issues, however. On a similar note, the game has some bugs for Windows 7 users, as the game was designed around Windows XP. I suggest doing some homework before you play the game to find some fan patches that fix a number of issues on newer machines, make some trial-and-error parts of the game easier, and make the game look better graphically.

It's not perfect, but I do think it's a good horror title, and worth checking out if you either have interest in horror games or Lovecraft mythos (as its mine and many others personal favorite Lovecraftian-inspired game). It does require some patience though, but there is an excellent experience here if you enjoy this sort of thing.

reviewText:
Positive
+ The sanity system, while confusing at first, does effectively emulate the effects of insanity, and the inflictions it has on the player are, quite simply put: enthralling
+ The Lovecraftian horror elements sprinkled throughout the story create a legitimately scary and unique experience that few games can emulate
+ The voice acting for the main character and the numerous surrounding characters you interact with during the game is exceptional, enrapturing you into the story even more so
+ At approximately 9 hours in length (on Private Investigator difficulty), the game is the perfect length for the material it is adapting.


Negative
- An untold amount of glitches. From numerous random game crashes and falling through the game world several times, to an unfinishable ending sequence (on modern hardware) without editing game files; this is easily the most buggy and glitch-ridden game I have ever played [Note: While the community has released numerous patches that reduce the amount of glitches that occur, this is still not enough to warrant not giving this aspect of the game a negative score.]
- The gun gameplay is mediocre at best, with indications of the damage you inflict on enemies and take yourself being vague to say the least.


Verdict
‚ÄúCall of Cthulhu: Dark Corners of the Earth is a unique experience. On the one hand, the amount of bugs this game has can easily put off any gamer from playing it. This game is gr8
There are a lot of bugs (a lot of them making it unplayable)
And the game is ANNOYINGLY unpolished

But despite the failure to distiguish itself from a game like Doom or a game like Amnesia.... CoC (that abbrv...sorry kids) is pretty cool when it comes to the story. The characters are nice enough and the story is compelling enough where I spent a great all-nighter enthralled in the fruits of this adventure game meant to be played in the dark...only to find when the sun rose outside the game wasn't as scary. Still the fact that I stayed up THAT late playing this game made it lovely enough for my books!

However, I think this game is OK to pass up if you're looking for a horror game to $h1t your pants. There are a lot of moments where I couldn't take CoC seriously as a horror game. Sometimes I didn't really know WHAT kind of game I was playing, and a lot of story elements made me question whether it was actually possible for ANYONE to get scared by these things.

This was also a 2006 game with probable 2001 quality.

If you get this game from a humble bundle, or a Steam sale pack, give it a go! It's not a totally crap game, and despite the bugs, and gut-wrenching unpolished nature of the game, I DID want to play this the second I got home from work. It was compelling enough!!!! Although the story isn't AMAZING, and although gameplay is a little shoddy, there are some gems I think opimistic gamers can appreciate with this game, there is certainly a soul this game has that not a lot of others have.

By the game-breaking bugs/crashes alone, and annoying unpolished nature...I would say to PASS it up. But besides that, I don't think it's completely crap, so if you happen to find this in your library (and can ignore a few flaws), give it a go! You will have a nice 10+ hours...if you don't go insane!

I happened to play this game back in 2005 when it came out. It stood out with it's great horror element, tough puzzles and the outstanding incorporation of the Lovecraft universe. For a huge Lovecraft fan, like myself, the latter was the reason to pick up this title once more, after ten years.

Now, there are a some cons to point out:

- The game hasn't aged well when compared to other games of 2005 like Call Of Duty 2, Battlefield 2, Doom 3, GTA: San Andreas, Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory. On 1920x1200 display the graphics gets pixelated and the low-resolution textures start to hurt the eye.

- The AI is crazy stupid. If you're far enough, enemies won't react to you shooting at them. If you shoot enemies from close distance, they rather react to the sound of the gun than taking damage. At times enemies would fail to shoot at you because there's some obstacle in their way, blocking the gun.

- The depth of field is so low that enemies will see you before you see them

- Dark Corners Of The Earth was designed to be a stealth game. You've got the 'crouch' option, the 'sneak' option and the game also tells you to hide in the shadows, to avoid detection. The reality is much more simple: if the enemy is turned towards you, he will see you and if he's turned the other way, he won't. Being in sneak mode or in shadows won't affect detection at all. The only differece is between walking or crouching, as one makes more sound than the other and that's the only part of 'stealthiness' that they did get to work.

- Lengthy unskippable cutscenes right before some of the toughest places of the game, which you then have to endure over and over every time you die.

Having said that, the pros are still there as well:

+ The atmosphere is still damn gloomy with absolutely superb looking Innsmouth and it's degenrate citizens.

+ The way you go from being a sneaky mouse to having the upper hand with considerable firepower carries the idea of remarkable character evolvement.

+ The horrors are revealed to you piece by piece, delivering the expected theatrical effect.

+ The story is typical Lovecraft - you stumble upon something unpleasant and get pulled into unimaginable horrors. Then it's your duty to struggle to stay alive while not going completely mad from everything that's being exposed to you.

+ Voice acting was one thing that echoed in my mind through all these years. I don't think I'm overstating when I say that the voice acting was perfect. The way the 'affected ones' struggle to sound articulate and finally fail to do so as the game advances is an experience of itself. 'Halt stranger!' will be something that will ring in your ears for a long time, shouted in a robust, disturbing voice.

+ Dark Corners Of The Earth is not an easy game, you have to struggle even with the lowest difficulty, getting shot or falling from a height will hurt a lot and health packages/save points are scarce. Fortunately you're packed with considerable firepower, so you've got the teeth to bite back.

Verdict:

Throughout the years Dark Corners Of The Earth has stayed one of the most memorable and bright horror survival experiences. They've nailed it with atmosphere and it definitely deserves the attention.

reviewText:
Is this game any good? That is a good question.
If you are a fan of Lovecrafts work and/or lovecraftian horror in general then this is indeed the game for you. But is it any good in a technical way?

Oh gee whiz it is a catastrophe!
When I first bought the game back then I played it for 30 minutes until I encountered the first crash. And it will not crash occasionally. There are specific locations or objects where the game will crash 99% of the time.

FIrst level: Going down the stairs into the basement? Crash!
Second level: Entering a room where a dead body hangs? Freeze!
Third level: Trying to push a shelf? CRASH!
Fourth level: Trying to push another shelf? CRASH!

You will see yourself download and use savegame-files from other players soon enough.

But the atmosphere, the story based on The Shadow over Innsmouth, the horror, some nice puzzles: It is all there and it is superb. Yes, the graphics are a little dated but it is an old, hugely flawed gem.

So? If you are a fan of HPL / horror, thick-skinned and you know that there are game-breaking bugs before you buy it then I can higly recommend this game for you!

As a Lovecraft fan I was really happy to get this grab this game on sale.  Just as I had hoped, the game is dark and gritty and thrusts you into the shoes of a struggling powerless investigator in a scary dangerous world filled with bad people and terrible unimaginable evil.

That said... this game has been a huge disappointment, consisting mostly of poorly implemented stealth and shallow gun-play.  I loved stealthing through the Hitman series, but staying hidden in COC just feels like a chore.  Fortunately, the enemy's aim / AI is so poor that blasting through most levels is fairly easy.  But again... so many other games offer better gunplay with smarter AI so why bother?

More importantly... bugs abound.  In order to get the game to work at all on Windows 8 required installation of unofficial patches / mods.  Even after their installation, the game will crash every time I push an object if I don't look away from doors/windows.  Moreover, several times I have passed through walls, onto roofs, or otherwise broken through the game allowing me to skip large portions of that chapter.  Although it was funny the first time, it breaks the tension and ruins any horror effect there should have been.

The gritty mystery makes me want to like the game, but I cannot recommend.

reviewText:
The concept is good. The horror and the atmosphere is there, especially in the first half of the game. The are some ideas that were quite a novelty back in 2005, like the sanity, no hud, lack of weapons and general fragility of your character.

Unfotunately, the game is broken in many ways. First of all, it didn't age well. Unless you're playing on XP, It's impossible to finish without unofficial patch that can be found on the forums. It does not support widescreen properly, and since it is a port from the first xbox, the graphics are so-so even by 2005 standards. Being a hastily port, it has many bugs. There are bugs that force you to reload from the last save game, and bugs that manifest themselves *when* you reload from the previous save. And a bunch of minor bugs, that are simply annoying.

But it's not only technical issues that spoil the fun. Many parts simply don't work as the creators intended. You may call it 'hard' but I call it 'badly designed':
- Some of the stealth sequences are next to impossible to pass unnoticed and are much easier if you simply 'run for it'.
- Some puzzles give absolutely no clue what to do next, and you wander aimlessly around the level searching for that one object that can be picked up, or interacted with.
- Some levels are trial-by-death type. You'll die at least several times untill you finally find out where exactly you have to go or what to do next. Given that save points are rare and can be missed entirely, plus many scripted secquences are unskippable, this quickly gets frustrating.

The combat, when you finally get some weapons, is difficult, but that's fine. Your character is not a Rambo (even though he can carry eight weapons, several books, medkits and a diary at the same time).

To sum up, only play this game if you are deep into Cthulhu mythos or you're out of horror games.  Otherwise, there are many better ways to spend 10 hours of your life.

For an FPS horror detective game with stealth elements, this game has only obvious mysteries, terrible pacing, and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• stealth.

I labored through this game for hours, employing a walkthrough for most of it because it's so hopelessly broken in so many parts.  I've never given a negative review. Typically, I just don't say anything about a game with which I've had a seemingly negative experience. In this case, however, I'm compelled to warn others not to waste their money.

It is, as a whole, a plea for better quality control from Steam for older titles and platform ports.  There are several showstopper bugs/freezes, unresolved collision problems, GPU compatibility issues, and scripting errors. If it was free, I could forgive most of that considering that I was able to make it through about 90% of the game.  But it isn't. I paid for it and it doesn't work as assumedly intended or described.

Save your dollars and frustrations for something that, while perhaps not as ambitious (a framework for something interesting was there), doesn't leave you feeling so cheated.

reviewText:
Some horror games stand above all others in delivering a polished, terrifying experience.  Call of Cthulhu: Dark Corners of the Earth...is NOT one of those games.  This game is the definition of a buggy, terrible, unintuitive nightmare.  You will be scared, but not because of the lovecraftian nightmares chasing you, but because of the crap game itself.

I picked this up on the recommendation of many people, who cited it's atmosphere and story as the selling points.  And, to be fair, the atmosphere is oppressive, nightmarish, and very unsettling, while the story is pretty decent, a nice introduction to lovecraft for those who haven't or don't want to read his writings, for whatever reason.

HOWEVER!  This game has far too many problems for anyone to want to play.  First the control scheme is terrible.  For an FPS it's decent enough, but the controls require you to be nose to nose with an item or enemy before you can use it or attack it.  Also, the game is built like an FPS, but in the first half of the game, you are completely weaponless and defenseless...not very smart.  Second, the game is incredibly unintuitive.  Almost nothing is explained in terms of gameplay and nothing that you need to do is made clear.  Passages to the next section are buried in crawlspaces or hidden so well that 30 minutes of searching is required to even dream of moving forward.  It feels like a point and click adventure that was badly shoved into an FPS.  The gunplay and healing is different, as the weapons are from the 1920s and require manual reloads, like the shot gun which can only fire two shots before being reloaded.  The healing happens in real time, so you have to plan the where and when to heal.  That would be fine, but you die so easily from even the most minor of wounds and the aiming is so awful that enemies will FREQUENTLY kill you.

And that's another thing.  The first time you try a section, your pulse will pound, your heart will race, and you'll feel really exhilirated because of how tense and scary it is.  The fifteenth time you try a section, you will want to scream at the screen for how buggy and unintuitive the section is.  The game loses its mystique of horror when you have to constantly reload saves to redo a section over and over again because of a mistake where you don't know what to do or don't know what you're doing wrong.  This game is so frustratingly unfun that I had to quite at one section where the glitches and poor game design just broke me.  One section of the game requires that you fire a cannon at 3 blue lights to trigger an event.  Problem.  There are NO BLUE LIGHTS.  The game's graphics are buggy and glitched so that sections like that are nigh on unplayable, and those are only for starters.  The platforming, yes there is platforming, is equally unplayable and unfun.

The only reason at all to play this would be for the story, and for that, you can go to the youtubes.  Greatest horror game of all time my butt.  This game is a buggy mess.  Cthulhu and Lovecraft deserve better.  Stay far away from this piece of gargabe.

reviewText:
(Before reading further, realize that my hours logged are not accurate as I was in offline mode for most of the time I played this. In reality I got a few hours in.)

Call of Cthulhu is a good adventure game that was killed by the malignant tumors of terrible action and terrible stealth. My attempts at playing showed me something important about videogames: the enjoyability of a game's story will be bottlenecked by the enjoyability of the gameplay because one must play the game to progress through the story.

The game starts out as a first person adventure game that gives you interesting puzzles, environments, and notes about the world. Everything this game needed to be great was more or less present in the introductory stage.

But everything falls apart once fishmen start trying to kill you. It took me several tries to escape the first room where the action starts. The game requires a fairly specific sequence of actions in a limited time, and if you don't divine what the developper wants you to do, then gameplay can devolve into trial and error. Trial and error is the arch-nemesis of immersion, and immersion is all too vital for horror games. In other words, I didn't so much get a scary horror experience as I did a fishpeople themed level of McPixel.

And there are stealth sequences. The problem with those are that the stealth mechanics flat out don't work. If an enemy sees one square centimeter of you hiding in the shadows, then everyone knows your exact position. Moving quietly is so slow that it is impossible to cross the distances you need to cross without getting spotted. Your trials and your errors will once again make you try the same section over and over and your immersion once again is broken.

Of course, the game compensates for these issues by making fishpeople have aim that makes stormtroopers look like elite marksmen by comparision. A fishpeople with a double barrell shotgun five feet away has a good chance of missing you standing still. So if you are anything like me, you will probably be finding yourself dawdling circles around armed fishpeople because it is often the path of least resistance.

And guns. I will admit that the handguns and the rifle feel kind of nice, but that is kind of irrelevant. The game claims you should take cover during combat. The problem with that is that when you lean around cover, your sights don't line up right when you aim. And there is at least one level where I am certain that enemies were respawning.

There are more nitpicks I can make. Like how enemies disappear as soon as they die, further damaging your immersion. Or that the health system makes it such that if you get hit, you will become too crippled to get yourself out of danger.

I didn't make it too far into this game. I reached a point where I continued only because I hoped the game would start being enjoyable if I stuck with it. I've learned that if I ever reach such a point, I should probable stop wasting my life on such a game.

There is promise in this game, but the problems are so annoying and so overhwelming that I can not recommend this game to anyone. The promise of Lovecraft's world being made real is bundled with some truly awful gameplay that would take extreme tolerence to plod through.

reviewText:
The Good: This game presents Lovecraft's Cthulhu mythos fairly well. It ties various elements of his fiction together to present a mostly coherent narrative. The story is far from exceptional but functions well for the game as it was intended. For those familiar with Lovecraft's work you will spend a great deal of the game in Innsmouth dealing with the deep ones but there are other encounters including the yith and a shoggoth. The game is also tied closely to the COC pnp game and it's fiction. The setting is fairly well realized and the gameplay has some interesting elements, including a health system that focused on different types of wounds on different parts of the body and a sanity system. Stealth is important and resources are in low supply. Various item combinations are required to treat different wounds. If you break a limb it will effect your movement and controls until you use a splint. You will hobble slowly or have a hard time aiming. As your sanity drops your vision is effected and you will suffer both visual and auditory hallucinations. The game is at it's best when you are struggling to survive, injured and going mad, fearful of every perceived threat.

The Bad: This is a poor PC port and a fan made patch is practically essential to play the game (look for the unofficial patch in the guides section). This is an older console game and certainly feels like it. The controls are a bit clunky and the save system is unpleasant. Some segments of the game are just a slog to get through. The psychological horror of Lovecraft's work is largely missing once you get further into the game, replaced with creepy atmosphere and monsters. The gunplay is also overdone further into the game and it's not very satisfying. The game unfortunately swings between survival horror and FPS action. While the survival horror aspects are fairly well done the action is not, and is simply out of place considering the setting.

Final Verdict: If you are a fan of Lovecraft or the Cthulhu mythos you should consider checking this game out. It has enough possitive qualities that make it an enjoyable, if not somewhat unfulfilling, trip to Innsmouth. If you are a fan of neither do not spend you're money here.

The Good: This game presents Lovecraft's Cthulhu mythos fairly well. It ties various elements of his fiction together to present a mostly coherent narrative. The story is far from exceptional but functions well for the game as it was intended. For those familiar with Lovecraft's work you will spend a great deal of the game in Innsmouth dealing with the deep ones but there are other encounters including the yith and a shoggoth. The game is also tied closely to the COC pnp game and it's fiction. The setting is fairly well realized and the gameplay has some interesting elements, including a health system that focused on different types of wounds on different parts of the body and a sanity system. Stealth is important and resources are in low supply. Various item combinations are required to treat different wounds. If you break a limb it will effect your movement and controls until you use a splint. You will hobble slowly or have a hard time aiming. As your sanity drops your vision is effected and you will suffer both visual and auditory hallucinations. The game is at it's best when you are struggling to survive, injured and going mad, fearful of every perceived threat.

The Bad: This is a poor PC port and a fan made patch is practically essential to play the game (look for the unofficial patch in the guides section). This is an older console game and certainly feels like it. The controls are a bit clunky and the save system is unpleasant. Some segments of the game are just a slog to get through. The psychological horror of Lovecraft's work is largely missing once you get further into the game, replaced with creepy atmosphere and monsters. The gunplay is also overdone further into the game and it's not very satisfying. The game unfortunately swings between survival horror and FPS action. While the survival horror aspects are fairly well done the action is not, and is simply out of place considering the setting.

Final Verdict: If you are a fan of Lovecraft or the Cthulhu mythos you should consider checking this game out. It has enough possitive qualities that make it an enjoyable, if not somewhat unfulfilling, trip to Innsmouth. If you are a fan of neither do not spend you're money here.

This game has a great sense of atmosphere that really captures the sanity-shattering cosmic horror of Lovecraft's writings, and of the Call of Cthulhu paper-and-pencil RPG.

The story itself does a good job of using Lovecraft's original stories, combining and expanding on his works. It's not a typical FPS that solely focuses on killing lots of enemies. You don't even get a weapon until quite a while through the game!  The latter acts become more heavily combat-oriented, but the focus is always on the narrative. The play experience is pretty linear, but it still manages to create the sense of exploration, mystery, terror, and fun of the old-school RPG--and the immersive atmosphere (e.g. no HUD, storytelling journal entries, puzzles that require talking to NPCs and checking notes to solve, sanity effects that alter your character's perceptions of reality, occasional insane muttering from the protagonist) really makes this game shine.

There are some bugs in the retail release, but don't let that turn you off of this purchase. There are community-made patches that fix the game-breaking bugs, and also let you tweak and enhance the gameplay. If you're a fan of the Cthulhu mythos or of survival horror in general, I would highly recommend this game.

The true horror of this game is that it runs like constipation. I couldn't watch a cutscene in this game without the whole thing bugging out. However, if you can get it to move, either through sheer force or dumb luck, then the first third of the game is a real treat and one of the best introductions I have ever played, especially the hotel scene in particular.

However, as many have stated, once the game gives you a firearm, the game turns into a pretty mediocre shooter.  It's not terrible at this point, but it's not very good either. Sure, you could still stealth, but there's no point in doing so when the AI has hawk vision yet can't aim their firearms at all.

Still, the first third of the game makes it worth it, if you can get the game on sale. And if you do plan on continuing to play it, keep a walkthrough handy. For the record, I really wish Steam would add a neutral button, because I'm really so torn about this game.  On one hand, it has a very good story, and even though graphically it's a bit obsolete, the atmosphere is fantastic, as is the script and the overall world of the game (despite its owing most of its allure to H.P. Lovecraft); but then there are just so many problems.

First, WASD has been the standard movement setup for first-person PC games for as long as I've been playing them, so why in the world the developers chose to make 's' the action button is beyond me.  It's not a tactical shooter like Rainbow 6 for ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•'s sake; it's a simple game that's not demanding whatsoever in the key mapping department.  They could have made 'e' the action button which it almost always is, and to be fair, it wouldn't have been a problem to just change it manually, but that still leaves the monumental and incredibly frustrating problem of not being able to backpedal (this becomes much more of a problem in the second half of the game when you get guns and it turns into more of a shooter than a stealth game).  Secondly, the controls; whether you're trying to be stealthy or aggressive are just unbelievably clunky and awkward.  It's as if someone intentionally designed the control scheme to be an undending source of frustration for the player, and I could understand this being a way of trying to simulate  the awkwardness of being a nobody who doesn't know how to handle guns, but you learn at the beginning of the game that the main character used to be a distinguished detective in the Boston Police Department, so he probably knows what he's doing as far as that goes.  Thirdly, the pacing of this game is absolutely horrendous and it's got to be one of the most long-winded, arduous (though still somewhat compelling) games I've ever played in my life, which is a shame considering how good the story actually is.

This game is unpolished, awkward, and while it can be fun at times, the story is the only thing keeping the player interested, and even that doesn't progress fast enough to keep things fresh.  It tries to be both a stealth and an action game, but really ends up failing at both.  The control scheme is the coffin, every nail in the coffin, and a Steinway grand piano falling 100 stories to crush what's left of this grand disapointment into a million broken, rotting pieces.  Wait for a sale, or you're wasting your money.  6.5/10

reviewText:
As much as I love Lovecraftian Horror, it is cringe worthy to note that not EVERY unholy being spawned from it is worth the experience. *coughcoughwhereiscthulhunotsomecamocoughcough*

Now, this negative review doesn't mean the game is completely bad. I did do some stream stuff in the past and I genuinely did enjoy the initial impact. A certain sequence towards the start of the game is worth noting for being one of my most favorite escape sequences of all time in gaming thus far. Bonus points for barging into someones room as they were snoozing and hearing them scream like a little b**** as you made your exit. However, the appeal does not last very long.

To start things out, this game has not aged well. While it can be argued about the graphics of the time, this is taken into a whole rather than just one aspect.

Graphics wise, it is kinda crap. some rather bland textures, stiff animations, and some model designs come into question. I do understand that horror needs some kind of tone, and the color schemes can help portray the sense of oppression, but it still seems rather lack luster here. What praise does come from is when they nail the setting spot on. Walking into a corridor riddled with corrosive slime and turning to go up some stair only to find some bloke with most of his body melted. That was a nice touch. However, they fail to keep that tension on the visual specturm in some cases, and the terror does fade in most cases.

As for sound to lend to the atmosphere, it's rather... bland. Voice acting fails to convey feeling in a lot of the dialogue, on the exception of going insane. Even in enemies as you listen to some side conversations. I understand you have some folks turning into fish people and such a thing can probably do a number on the vocal cords, but the state of what they used leaves more to be desired.  As for the spots where music does play, it does add some tension, admittedly. However, I'm not giving it brownie points, and I do genuinely like that in most cases you are left in silence for the most part, taking in your surroundings by ear. Plus, hearing *spoiler cut* down certain areas of the game can leave a slight chill down your spine as your foot steps echo.

Gameplay is mostly the weak part of the game. It features puzzles, action, stealth, and using your head to some extent. Some puzzles are rather easy, and the harder ones need a bit digging to solve, which some appreciation is had. Going through found logs and notes, checking some backstories to some of the lore is nice. But there is a fine line between using your head and wasting time, which the game does harp on that said line. I forgot how long I was trecking through a mansion trying to figure out the proper way to go, only to find out a certain thing was a breakable wall after getting upset and randomly wandering about. Combat is standard FPS, with iron sights and limited ammo, and I do like how you lack telepathy or a hud to see health or ammo, with the inventory system showing health and what you have, similar to old school 'Silent Hill' but much MUCH dumbed down. But it does get tedious and almost dreadful. Stealth ISN'T perfect, but at least its not the worst kind of stealth where you easily get spotted or something along those lines. Hiding spots are a little obvious, and there is a breath holding mechanic in place to mask your presence, along with leaning out from cover to look at foes. So there's that.

As for story... it's not exactly original. Take 'Shadow Over Innsmouth' and mix in a few other things to increase game time. About sums it up. I really find it hard to explain the story, and I can't tell if its a good or bad thing. It's the generic staple of Lovecraft: Investigator goes to investigate something and gets drawn into something more dark and complex that the normal human mind fails to understand. I'm not going to spoil too much for the sake of not wasting time. Lovecraft fans can easily brace themselves for it. And if not a fan, go and read the story mentioned in the second sentence of this paragraph. Gives a lot of perspective on things.

While the game isn't TERRIBLE and is playable, there are some things that irk me up the wrong way. There are better titles, and there are worse ones as well. Mediocre at best. But not going to be giving it any gold stars any time soon or in the future. Most I can really say is that if you're an extreme fan of the dark mind of Lovecraft, give it a go for the sake of being a fan.

Oh man, this game. This game could have been glorious, even with its age and its problematic source material. There are some great interpretations of Lovecraft's source material, especially Innsmouth's denizens and some other creatures. Of the smattering of Cthulhu mythos inspired games out there, this is easily the best. That doesn't mean there aren't plenty of drawbacks, however.

The game, technically, is kind of a mess. Checkpointing in each stage is poorly laid out, often leading to a lot of tedious and/or rage-inducing repetition of sections. If you use multiple monitors, there's another issue; be sure to find a program that locks your mouse to one monitor, or you'll be clicking out of game (thus minimizing or crashing it) fairly often when you're trying to aim or move. Several sections are buggy, including the final boss fight, which often fails to spawn in things you need to finish said fight. As I said, it's kind of a mess.

Thankfully, there are fan patches out there that fix a fair amount, if not all, of these issues. I played without them due to lack of awareness, so I imagine tracking those down might make your experience that much better. I'm going to give this a tenuous recommend because, again, it's the best Lovecraft-inspired game ever. But seriously, do your homework, patch up, and go in prepared.
